cleaned_text: vitamin E by Maret G. Traber, Ph.D. Summary - Naturally occurring vitamin E includes eight fat-soluble isoforms: -, -, -, and -tocopherol and -, -, -, and -tocotrienol. Yet, the body preferentially uses -tocopherol, and only -tocopherol supplementation can reverse vitamin E deficiency symptoms. [(More information)](#introduction) - -Tocopherol functions as a chain-breaking [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant), radicals](../glossary#free-radical) in membranes and [plasma](../glossary#plasma) [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein). -Tocopherol is also likely involved in strengthening certain aspects of cell-mediated immunity. [(More information)](#antioxidant-activity) - Vitamin E deficiency can be caused by fat malabsorption disorders or by genetic abnormalities that affect vitamin E transport. Severe deficiency symptoms include vitamin E deficiency-induced [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia), [peripheral neuropathy](../glossary#peripheral-neuropathy), muscle weakness, and damage to the [retina](../glossary#retina) of the eye. [(More information)](#deficiency) - The current recommended dietary allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) is 15 mg/day of -tocopherol. It is estimated that more than 90% of Americans adults do not meet the estimated average requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)) of 12 mg/day of -tocopherol. [(More information)](#RDA) - trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) investigating [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease), such as [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease), [cancer](../glossary#cancer), and [cataracts](../glossary#cataract), do not currently support a preventative effect of supplemental -tocopherol. [(More information)](#cardiovascular-disease-prevention) - Limited [clinical evidence](../glossary#clinical-trial) suggests that vitamin E supplementation may be beneficial for managing age-related macular degeneration and fatty liver diseases secondary to [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). [(More information)](#disease-treatment) - Supplementation with -tocopherol was found to slow [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) decline or loss of functional abilities in cognitively impaired subjects in some, but not all, clinical studies. [(More information)](#cognitive-deterioration-alzheimer-disease-treatment) - Plant seeds, especially sunflower seeds, almonds, and hazelnuts, are rich sources of -tocopherol such that many vegetable oils (e.g., olive oil and canola oil) also contain -tocopherol. Other sources include tomato, avocado, spinach, asparagus, Swiss chard, broccoli. [(More information)](#food-sources) - High doses of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) -tocopherol may interfere with the vitamin K-dependent blood clotting cascade and increase the risk of bleeding in individuals taking [anticoagulant](../glossary#anticoagulant) drugs. A tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for -tocopherol in adults is set at 1,000 mg/day and applies to all possible stereoisomers of -tocopherol. [(More information)](#safety) The term vitamin E describes a family of eight fat-soluble molecules with [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) activities: four tocopherol isoforms (-, -, -, and -tocopherol) and four tocotrienol isoforms (-, -, -, and -tocotrienol) (Figure 1). Only one form, -tocopherol, meets human vitamin E requirements (see [The RDA](#RDA)). In the human liver, -tocopherol is the form of vitamin E that is preferentially bound to -tocopherol transfer protein (-TTP) and incorporated into [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) that transport -tocopherol in the blood for delivery to extrahepatic tissues. Therefore, it is the predominant form of vitamin E found in the blood and tissues [(1)](#references). In addition, -tocopherol appears to be the form of vitamin E with the greatest nutritional significance, such that it will be the primary topic of the following discussion. [[Figure 1 - Click to Enlarge]](/sites/lpi.oregonstate.edu/files/vitamin-e-figure-1-1200px.png) Function -Tocopherol Natural versus synthetic -tocopherol Natural -tocopherol made by plants found in food has an RRR-configuration at the 2, 4', and 8'-position of the -tocopherol molecule (wrongly referred to as d--tocopherol) (see [Figure 1](#figure-1)). Chemically synthesized all-rac--tocopherol (all-racemic--tocopherol; incorrectly labeled dl--tocopherol) is a mixture of eight stereoisomers of -tocopherol, which arose from the three chiral equal [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) activity, only the forms in the R-conformation at position 2 (noted 2R) meet the vitamin E requirements in humans [(2)](#reference2). Antioxidant activity The main function of -tocopherol in humans is that of a fat-soluble [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant). Fats, which are an integral part of all [cell membranes](../glossary#cell-membrane), are vulnerable to damage through [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation) by [free radicals](../glossary#free-radical). -Tocopherol is uniquely suited to intercept peroxyl radicals and thus prevent a chain reaction of [lipid](../glossary#lipid) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) (Figure 2). When a molecule of -tocopherol neutralizes a free radical, it is oxidized and its antioxidant capacity is lost. Other antioxidants, such as [vitamin C](vitamin-C), are capable of regenerating the antioxidant capacity of -tocopherol (Figure 2) (reviewed in [1](#references)). Aside from maintaining the integrity of cell membranes throughout the body, -tocopherol protects the fats in low-density lipoproteins ( [LDLs](../glossary#LDL)) from oxidation. Lipoproteins are particles composed of lipids and [proteins](../glossary#protein) that transport fats through the bloodstream. LDLs specifically transport [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) from the liver to the tissues of the body. Oxidized LDLs have been implicated in the development of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(3)](#reference3). [[Figure 2 - Click to Enlarge]](/sites/lpi.oregonstate.edu/files/vitamin-e-figure-2-1200px.png) Effects on cell-mediated immunity Other functions of -tocopherol are likely to be related to its [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) capacity [(1)](#references). For instance, -tocopherol can protect the physiological properties of [lipid](../glossary#lipid) bilayer membranes and may influence the activity of membrane [proteins](../glossary#protein) and [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) [(4)](#reference4). In cell culture studies, -tocopherol was found to improve the formation of an adhesive junction (known as immune synapse) between naïve T [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) and [antigen](../glossary#antigen)-presenting cells (APC), which eventually prompted (see [Disease Prevention](#aging-immune-function)) [(5, 6)](#reference5). -Tocopherol and tocotrienols Vitamin E forms other than -tocopherol are also known to be potent [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant). Tocotrienols and -tocopherol are thought to be better scavengers of peroxyl radicals and [reactive nitrogen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species), respectively, than -tocopherol [(7)](#reference7). Yet, in the body, (1) -tocopherol is preferentially retained in the liver by the binding to -tocopherol transfer protein (-TTP), which incorporates -tocopherol into [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) for delivery to extrahepatic tissues; and (2) forms of vitamin E other than -tocopherol are actively [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) and [excreted](../glossary#excretion). Hence, while -tocopherol is the most common form of vitamin E in the American diet [(8)](#reference8), its [plasma](../glossary#plasma) and tissue concentrations are generally significantly lower than those of -tocopherol, and more -tocopherol is excreted in urine than -tocopherol, suggesting less -tocopherol is needed for use by the body [(1)](#references). Studies conducted [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) and in animals have indicated that -tocopherol and its major metabolite, -carboxyethyl hydroxychroman (-CEHC), may play a role in protecting the body from [free radical](../glossary#free-radical)-induced damage in various conditions of [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and (reviewed in [7](#reference7)). Limited [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) (highlighted in [7](#reference7)) have not convincingly demonstrated a potential anti-inflammatory effect of -tocopherol in humans. Yet, in two recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled studies, the supplementation of smokers with -tocopherol potentiated short-term benefits of smoking cessation (with or without nicotine replacement therapy) on [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) function [(9, 10)](#reference9). Numerous preclinical studies have also suggested that tocotrienols might be beneficial in the prevention of [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease) [(11)](#reference11). For instance, tocotrienols (especially -tocotrienol) have [proliferative](../glossary#proliferation) and pro- [apoptotic](../glossary#apoptosis) effects than tocopherols in [malignant](../glossary#malignant) cell lines [(12)](#reference12). However, a number of factors, including dose, formulation, and type of study population, affect the [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of tocotrienols and may undermine their putative efficacy in humans [(13)](#reference13). There are currently no data available on the effectiveness of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) tocotrienols in humans [(11)](#reference11). Nutrient interactions Dietary and circulating fatty acids The mechanism of vitamin E digestion and uptake into intestinal cells ( [enterocytes](../glossary#enterocyte)) is unclear but requires [bile acids](../glossary#bile-acids) and [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), and the packaging along with dietary fat into [chylomicrons](../glossary#chylomicron). The efficiency of vitamin E absorption increases with the amount of fat in ingested food, such that vitamin E absorption from supplements is likely to be minimal with low-fat meals [(14, 15)](#reference14). In the circulation, all [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein) (i.e., VLDLs, [LDLs](../glossary#LDL), and [HDLs](../glossary#HDL)) are involved in the transport and tissue distribution of -tocopherol [(1)](#references). Increased concentrations of [lipids](../glossary#lipid) ( [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) and [triglycerides](../glossary#triglycerides)) the blood have been correlated to higher [serum](../glossary#serum) -tocopherol concentrations. However, if a high blood concentration of lipids is associated with a slower turnover of lipoproteins, then the distribution of -tocopherol to tissues may be substantially altered [(16)](#reference16). Vitamin C A few human studies using conditions of [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) have demonstrated the importance of [vitamin C](vitamin-C) (ascorbic acid) in the recycling of [oxidized](../glossary#oxidation) -tocopherol back to its reduced state (see [Figure 2](#figure-2)). Oxidative stress caused by cigarette smoking accelerates the depletion of [plasma](../glossary#plasma) -tocopherol in smokers compared to nonsmokers [(17)](#reference17). In a [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 11 smokers and 13 nonsmokers given -tocopherol and -tocopherol that was labeled with deuterium (hence traceable), supplementation with vitamin C reduced the rate of vitamin E loss in plasma, most probably by regenerating tocopheryl radicals back to nonoxidized forms [(18)](#reference18). Vitamin K One study in adults with normal coagulation (clotting) status found that daily supplementation with 1,000 IU (670 mg) of RRR--tocopherol for 12 weeks decreased -carboxylation of prothrombin, a [vitamin K](vitamin-K)-dependent factor in the [coagulation](../glossary#coagulation) cascade [(19)](#reference19). Individuals taking [anticoagulant](../glossary#anticoagulant) drugs like warfarin and those who are vitamin K deficient should not take vitamin E [supplements](../glossary#supplement) without medical supervision because of the increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of bleeding (see [Safety](#safety)) [(20)](#reference20). Deficiency Causes Severe vitamin E deficiency rarely occurs in humans but has been observed as a result of malnutrition [(21)](#reference21). Severe vitamin E deficiency has been associated with specific genetic defects affecting the transport of -tocopherol by -tocopherol transfer protein (-TTP) and [lipoproteins](../glossary#lipoprotein). Vitamin E deficiency has also been observed in individuals with fat [malabsorption syndromes](../glossary#malabsorption-syndrome), which impair the absorption of dietary fats and therefore fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin E (see [Nutrient interactions](#nutrient-interactions)) [(21)](#reference21). Symptoms Severe vitamin E deficiency results mainly in [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) symptoms, including impaired balance and coordination (spinocerebellar [ataxia](../glossary#ataxia)), injury to the sensory nerves ( [peripheral neuropathy](../glossary#peripheral-neuropathy)), muscle weakness ( [myopathy](../glossary#myopathy)), and damage to the [retina](../glossary#retina) of the eye (retinopathy). For this reason, people who develop peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, or retinitis pigmentosa (RP) of unknown causes should be screened for vitamin E deficiency [(21)](#reference21). The results of one [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 601 patients with common forms of RP indicated that daily [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 400 IU of all-rac--tocopherol (180 mg of RRR--tocopherol) modestly but significantly increased the loss of retinal function [(22)](#reference22). In contrast, daily supplementation with 15,000 IU of vitamin A (4,500 g RAE) significantly slowed the loss of retinal function over a period of four to six years, suggesting that patients with common forms of RP may benefit from long-term vitamin A supplementation but should avoid high-dose supplemental vitamin E. Inherited defects in -TTP are associated with a characteristic syndrome called AVED (Ataxia with Vitamin E Deficiency). A recent case study reported that visual impairment in a middle-age patient with AVED was caused by both RP and early-onset macular degeneration [(23)](#reference23). Supplementation with high-dose vitamin E used to prevent neurologic deterioration in AVED subjects [(21)](#reference21). Moreover, the developing nervous system appears to be especially vulnerable to vitamin E deficiency. For instance, children with severe vitamin E deficiency at birth rapidly experience irreversible neurologic symptoms if not treated with vitamin E. In contrast, individuals who develop [gastrointestinal](../glossary#gastrointestinal) disorders affecting vitamin E absorption in adulthood may not develop neurologic symptoms for 10-20 years [(21)](#reference21). It should also be noted that neurologic symptoms caused by vitamin E deficiency have not been reported in healthy individuals who consume diets low in vitamin E. Marginal deficiency Although frank vitamin E deficiency is rare, marginal intake of vitamin E is relatively common. Between 1988 and 1994, the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey III (NHANES III) examined the dietary intake and blood concentrations of -tocopherol in 16,295 adults. The study reported that about one-third of all participants had blood concentrations of -tocopherol below 20 micromoles/liter (mol/L) — a cutoff value chosen because of its initial association with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) [(24)](#reference24). More recent data from 18,063 participants in NHANES 2003-2006 indicated an average dietary intake of -tocopherol from food (including enriched and [fortified](../glossary#fortification) sources) among Americans adults of 7.2 mg/day [(25)](#reference25). This intake is well below the current recommended dietary allowance of 15 mg/day (see [the RDA](#RDA)). At this level of dietary intake, more than 93% of American adults do not meet the estimated average requirement ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR)) of 12 mg/day for vitamin E [(25)](#reference25). In addition, a recent [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) in Bangladeshi women suggested that inadequate vitamin E status during early pregnancy may be associated with an increased risk of miscarriage [(26)](#reference26). Cigarette smoking is thought to increase the utilization of -tocopherol such that smokers might be at increased risk of deficiency compared with nonsmokers [(17)](#reference17). Also, the 19-year follow-up analysis of the Alpha-Tocopherol, Beta-Carotene cancer (ATBC) trial in older, male smokers indicated that participants in the highest versus lowest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of [serum](../glossary#serum) -tocopherol concentrations (>31 mol/L vs. <23 mol/L) at baseline had reduced risks of total and cause-specific mortality [(27)](#reference27). It is not known whether marginal vitamin E deficiency increases the risk of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease) [(1)](#references). The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) The [RDA](../glossary#RDA) for vitamin E was last revised by the Food and Nutrition Board of the US Institute of Medicine in 2000 (Table 1) [(2)](#reference2). The RDA is based largely on the results of studies done in the 1950s in men fed vitamin E-deficient diets. In a test-tube analysis, vitamin E suppresses the breakdown of red blood cells (known as [hemolysis](../glossary#hemolysis)) induced by hydrogen peroxide. Because hemolysis has also been reported in children with severe vitamin E deficiency, the preventive effect of vitamin E against oxidative damage-induced hemolysis was considered to be a clinically relevant [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) analysis to assess vitamin E status. Importantly, this means that the latest RDA for vitamin E continues to be based on the prevention of deficiency symptoms rather than on health promotion and prevention of [chronic disease](../glossary#chronic-disease). The forms of -tocopherol that meet the recommended intakes are RRR--tocopherol — the only naturally occurring form of vitamin E — and the three synthetic isomers, RRS-, RSR-, and RSS--tocopherol, which are found in nutritional [supplements](../glossary#supplement) and [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food. Table 1 lists the RDA for -tocopherol expressed in both milligrams (mg) and international units (IU). Table 1. Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for -Tocopherol*# | Life Stage || Age || 0-6 months || | 4 | | 6 | | 4 | | 6 | Infants (AI) || 7-12 months || | 5 | | 7.5 | | 5 | | 7.5 | Children || 1-3 years || | 6 | | 9 | | 6 | | 9 | Children || 4-8 years || | 7 | | 10.5 | | 7.5 | | 10.5 | Children || 9-13 years || | 11 | | 16.5 | | 11 | | 16.5 | Adolescents || 14-18 years || | 15 | | 22.5 | | 15 | | 22.5 | Adults || 19 years and older || | 15 | | 22.5 | | 15 | | 22.5 | Pregnancy || all ages || | - | | - | | 15 | | 22.5 | Breast-feeding || all ages || | - | | - | | 19 | | 28.5 | | *These recommended intakes are limited to 2R-stereoisomeric forms of -tocopherol. #One mg of 2R--tocopherol is equivalent to 1.5 IU, and one IU is equivalent to 0.67 mg of 2R--tocopherol. Disease Prevention Age-related deterioration of immune function The natural age-related decline of the immune function is accompanied by an increased susceptibility to infections, a poorer response to immunization, and higher [risks](../glossary#risk) of developing [cancers](../glossary#cancer) and [autoimmune diseases](../glossary#autoimmune-disease). -Tocopherol has been shown to enhance specifically the T cell-mediated immune response that declines with advancing age (reviewed in [28](#reference28)). T cell impaired response has been partly associated with a reduced capacity of naïve T cells to be activated during [antigen](../glossary#antigen) presentation, and to produce interleukin-2 (IL-2) and [proliferate](../glossary#proliferation) as a result [(6)](#reference6). However, very few studies have addressed the potential association between -tocopherol and immune function in humans [(28)](#reference28). In a small [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial) in older adults (mean age, 70 years), supplementation with 200 mg/day of all-rac--tocopherol (equivalent to 100 mg of RRR--tocopherol) for three months improved [natural killer](../glossary#natural-killer-cells) and interleukin-2 (IL-2) production compared to baseline [(29)](#reference29). In an earlier trial, daily supplementation of healthy older adults (65 years of age) with 200 mg of all-rac--tocopherol for 235 days also improved T lymphocyte-mediated immunity — as measured with the delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) skin test — and increased the production of [antibodies](../glossary#antibody) in response to [hepatitis](../glossary#hepatitis) B and tetanus vaccines [(30)](#reference30). Lower -tocopherol doses failed to improve the DTH response compared to a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) in another study in healthy participants (ages, 65-80 years) [(31)](#reference31). A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), placebo-controlled trial in 617 nursing home residents (65 years of age) reported that daily supplementation with 200 IU of synthetic -tocopherol (90 mg of RRR--tocopherol) for one year significantly lowered the risk of contracting upper respiratory tract infections, especially the common cold, but had no effect on lower respiratory tract (lung) infections [(32)](#reference32). More research is needed to examine whether supplemental vitamin E might enhance immune function and reduce risk of infection in older adults. Cardiovascular disease Primary prevention: in healthy adults Observational studies: Results of several large [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) in both men and women have suggested an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between vitamin E consumption and [risk](../glossary#risk) of [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) or death from heart disease. Each study had a [prospective](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) design that measured vitamin E intake in generally healthy people who were followed over a period of time to determine the onset of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events and analyze the association between the exposure and the outcome(s). In two of the studies, individuals who consumed more than 7 mg/day of dietary -tocopherol were 35% less likely to die from heart disease than those who consumed less than 3-5 mg/day of -tocopherol [(33, 34)](#reference33). Two other large studies observed a significantly reduced risk of heart disease only in women and men who consumed at least 100 IU (67 mg)/day of 39,876 women (aged 45 years) participating in the Women's Health Study (WHS) found that supplementation with 600 IU (400 mg) of RRR--tocopherol every other day for 10 years resulted in a 34% reduction in nonfatal [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) and a 49% reduction in cardiovascular-related deaths but only in women aged at least 65 years at baseline (representing 10% of study participants) [(37)](#reference37). Further analyses of WHS data showed that women in the vitamin E arm of the study experienced a 21% reduction in [risk](../glossary#risk) of venous thromboembolism (VTE) compared to placebo: the reduction was of 12% in women younger than 55 years old, 26% in women aged 65 years and older, and 44% in women with a history of VTE [(38, 39)](#reference38). Another large [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) — the Physicians' Health Study II (PHSII) — conducted in healthy middle-aged men found no significant effect of 400 IU of synthetic -tocopherol (180 mg of RRR--tocopherol), given every other day for eight years, on the risk of major cardiovascular events in the entire cohort and in subgroup analyses [(40)](#reference40). Besides, concerns were raised regarding a possible harmful effect of high-dose vitamin E supplementation on the risk of [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) in this cohort [(40)](#reference40). Secondary prevention: in individuals with or at risk of cardiovascular disease Conventional risk factors for [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD) include cigarette smoking, physical inactivity, [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), [dyslipidemia](../glossary#dyslipidemia), and being overweight or [obese](../glossary#obesity). Other factors such as [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) and [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) are also thought to contribute to increasing CVD risk, especially in patients with chronic conditions like type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and chronic kidney disease. Although trials do not appear to support any [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) benefit in healthy middle-aged and older subjects, vitamin E supplementation might help improve cardiovascular health and/or lower the risk of CVD in specific, higher risk subjects. Observational studies: The presence of [atherosclerotic](../glossary#atherosclerosis) plaques in arterial walls is one of the hallmarks of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease). Plaque rupture that causes blood clot formation is the usual cause of myocardial and cerebrovascular infarctions. The [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) Asymptomatic an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between [carotid](../glossary#carotid-arteries) intima-media thickness (CIMT) — a marker of [atherosclerosis](../glossary#atherosclerosis) — and circulating concentrations of [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant), including vitamin E [(41)](#reference41). However, other observational studies found no association between [plasma](../glossary#plasma) vitamin E concentrations and CIMT (reviewed in [42](#reference42)). Intervention studies: A small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) controlled study assessing the effect of lipid-lowering drugs in men who had previously undergone a coronary artery bypass surgery found that the use of at least 100 IU/day (compared to less than 100 IU/day) of supplemental -tocopherol (45 mg of RRR--tocopherol) was associated with reduced CIMT progression over a two-year period but only among participants in the [placebo](../glossary#placebo) arm of the study (i.e., those who did not receive lipid-lowering drugs) [(43)](#reference43). However, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven small placebo-controlled trials found little evidence that vitamin E supplementation may improve flow-mediated vascular dilation (FMD) of the brachial artery, a marker of [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) health that is adversely affected by CVD risk factors [(44)](#reference44). In the Cambridge Heart AntiOxidant Study (CHAOS), a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled [intervention trial](../glossary#intervention-trial) in 2,002 patients with [coronary heart daily supplementation with either 400 IU or 800 IU of synthetic -tocopherol (180 mg or 360 mg of RRR--tocopherol) for a median 18 months dramatically reduced the occurrence of nonfatal [myocardial infarctions](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) by 77%. However, vitamin E supplementation did not significantly reduce total or cardiovascular-related deaths [(45)](#reference45). Another small trial in patients with [renal](../glossary#renal) failure — the Secondary Prevention with Antioxidants of cardiovascular disease in End-stage renal disease (SPACE) — found that supplementation with 800 IU (536 mg)/day of RRR--tocopherol for an average of 1.4 years significantly reduced the risk of myocardial infarction compared to placebo [(46)](#reference46). A more recent randomized controlled study suggested that vitamin E supplementation may benefit a subgroup of patients with type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). The multicenter study by Milman et al. [(47)](#reference47) was conducted in 1,434 type 2 diabetics (55 years old) carrying a specific variant of the haptoglobin [protein](../glossary#protein) (Hp), Hp2-2, which has a lower efficacy to bind and remove [pro-oxidant](../glossary#pro-oxidant), free [hemoglobin](../glossary#hemoglobin) from [plasma](../glossary#plasma), compared to Hp1-1 and Hp1-2 variants. The daily supplementation with 400 IU (268 mg) of RRR--tocopherol for 18 months resulted in a lower risk of myocardial infarction compared to placebo [(47)](#reference47). Other larger intervention trials conducted in cigarette smokers (the Alpha-Tocopherol, Beta-Carotene cancer prevention [ATBC] study [(48)](#reference48)), in individuals at-risk of CVD (the Heart Outcomes Prevention Evaluation [HOPE]-The Ongoing Outcomes [HOPE-TOO study] [(49)](#reference49)), or in patients who have suffered a (Gruppo Italiano per lo Studio della trial [(50)](#reference50)) failed to find significant CVD risk reductions with -tocopherol supplementation. Besides, potentially harmful effects of supplemental vitamin E were reported on the risk of [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) in the ATBC trial and on the risk of heart failure in the HOPE and GISSI trials (see [Safety](#safety)) [(48-50)](#reference48). Cancer [Oxidative [free radicals](../glossary#free-radical) to [mutations](../glossary#mutation) that may contribute to causing [cancer](../glossary#cancer) [(51)](#reference51). Because of its ability to neutralize free radicals, vitamin E has been suggested to possess anticancer activity by protecting cells against oxidative damage. Yet, several large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have failed to find significant associations between vitamin E intake and the incidence of lung or breast cancer [(2)](#reference2). More recently, the VITamins And Lifestyle (VITAL) study prospectively assessed the association between long-term use of supplemental vitamins (10-year intake) and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of lung cancer in a cohort of 77,126 men and women [(52)](#reference52). No relationships were reported between intake of multivitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, or folate and the risk of lung cancer. However, the use of supplemental vitamin E in current but not in former smokers was associated with an 11% increased risk of lung cancer for every 100 mg/day increase, and intakes greater than 215 mg/day were specifically linked to a 29% increase in risk for non-small cell lung cancer [(52)](#reference52). To date, most [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have failed to find any beneficial effects of vitamin E supplementation on the risk of various cancers. A [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial (RCT) in 39,876 women participating in the Women's Health Study found that supplementation with 600 IU (400 mg) of RRR--tocopherol every other day for 10 years had no effect on overall cancer incidence, tissue-specific cancer incidence, or cancer-related deaths [(37)](#reference37). Yet, the results of a few large [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have suggested that vitamin E supplementation might affect the risk of [prostate](../glossary#prostate) cancer. The Alpha-Tocopherol, Beta-Carotene cancer (ATBC) prevention study was a four-arm, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial designed to investigate the effect of -tocopherol supplementation on lung cancer development in 29,133 male smokers. The study found a 32% reduction in the incidence of prostate cancer in participants given daily supplements of 50 mg of synthetic -tocopherol (equivalent to 25 mg of RRR--tocopherol) alone or in combination with -carotene compared to those given -carotene alone or a placebo [(53)](#reference53). However, no differences in the incidence of prostate cancer were found between -tocopherol recipients and nonrecipients during the 18-year post-intervention period [(54)](#reference54). In the Physicians' Health Study II (PHS II), which followed 14,641 healthy men aged 50 years and older, supplementation with 400 IU of synthetic vitamin E (equivalent to 180 mg of RRR--tocopherol) every other day for eight years had no effect on the risk of prostate cancer, other site-specific cancers, or total cancer [(55)](#reference55). The supplementation of vitamin E (equivalent to 180 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol), alone or in combination with selenium, in the multicenter, randomized, placebo-controlled SELECT trial (SELenium and vitamin E Cancer prevention Trial) was halted because there was no evidence of benefit in preventing prostate cancer in 35,533 healthy men aged 50 years and older [(56)](#reference56). After a median of seven years' follow-up, the risk of prostate cancer was found to be significantly increased by 17% in participants supplemented with vitamin E alone during the trial period — but not when vitamin E was combined with selenium — compared to placebo [(57)](#reference57). A study of cases versus subcohort individuals drawn from the SELECT study assessed the effect of vitamin E and/or selenium supplementation on prostate cancer risk in relation to the selenium status of participants at baseline [(58)](#reference58). Supplemental selenium with or without vitamin E was associated with a significant increase in the risk of advanced prostate cancer in individuals with higher versus lower selenium status. In addition, the risks of total and advanced prostate cancer were significantly elevated with vitamin E supplementation in subjects with low versus high selenium status [(58)](#reference58). Recent investigations have suggested that sequence variations ( [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism)) in vitamin E-related [genes](../glossary#gene) and genes coding for [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme), including selenoproteins, might modify the impact of high-dose vitamin E and selenium on the risk of prostate cancer [(59-61)](#reference59). Cataracts Age-related [cataracts](../glossary#cataract) appear to be the result of [protein](../glossary#protein) [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) in the [lens](../glossary#lens) of the eye; [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant) like may protect the lens against [oxidative from [reactive oxygen species](../glossary#reactive-oxygen-species). In a recent [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study), vitamin E concentrations were found to be significantly lower in the lens and blood of subjects with age-related nuclear, but not cortical, cataracts when compared with an age-matched control group [(62)](#reference62). However, earlier studies reported higher vitamin E concentrations in the lenses and blood of patients with cataracts [(63, 64)](#reference63). The results of several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined the association between vitamin E consumption and the incidence or severity of cataracts are also mixed. Some reported that increased vitamin E intake protected against cataract development, while others found no association [(65)](#reference65). Yet, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of eight studies, including 15,021 participants, found a 17% reduction in the risk of age-related cataract in subjects in the highest versus lowest quantile of dietary vitamin E intake [(66)](#reference66). A recent [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of 31,120 Swedish men followed for a mean of 8.4 years observed a greater risk of developing cataract in occasional and regular users of high-dose (about 100 mg/day) vitamin E supplements only, when compared with non-supplement users [(67)](#reference67). However, the use of supplemental high-dose vitamin E with additional supplements or the use of low-dose vitamin E-containing multivitamin supplements was not found to be associated with an elevated cataract risk. A meta-analysis based on data from over 350,000 participants in 10 studies — including the above-cited study by Zheng Selin et al. [(67)](#reference67) — found no association between supplemental vitamin E and risk of cataract [(66)](#reference66). In clinical settings, the supplementation of high-dose vitamin E — alone or in addition to other supplements — was found to be safe, yet the benefits regarding cataract risk or progression were limited. An early intervention trial found that a daily supplement of 50 mg of synthetic -tocopherol (equivalent to 25 mg of RRR--tocopherol) did not alter the incidence of cataract surgery in male smokers [(68)](#reference68). A randomized, placebo-controlled [intervention trial](../glossary#intervention-trial) in 4,629 men and women found that a daily antioxidant supplement containing 500 mg of vitamin C, 400 IU of all-rac--tocopheryl acetate (equivalent to 180 mg of RRR--tocopherol), and 15 mg of -carotene did not affect development and progression of age-related cataracts over a seven-year period [(69)](#reference69). Similarly, a four-armed, randomized, placebo-controlled study of 11,267 men from the Selenium and Vitamin E Cancer prevention trial (SELECT) failed to observe a reduction in cataract incidence with 400 IU/day of supplemental all-rac--tocopheryl acetate (180 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol), alone or in combination with selenium (200 g/day), during a mean 5.6 years of follow-up [(70)](#reference70). Daily antioxidant supplementation with 500 mg of vitamin C, 400 IU (268 mg) of RRR--tocopherol, and 15 mg of -carotene did not limit the progression of cataract in a five-year intervention trial [(71)](#reference71). Another four-year randomized, placebo-controlled trial reported that supplements containing 500 IU/day (335 mg/day) of RRR--tocopherol did not reduce the incidence or progression of cataract in older adults [(72)](#reference72). Current available data from [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) do not support a preventative effect of vitamin E on cataracts. Disease Treatment Age-related macular degeneration A recent pooled analysis of four [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 62,520 subjects found that [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) vitamin E or -carotene did not reduce the risk of developing age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a multifactorial disease affecting the central area of the [retina](../glossary#retina) [(73)](#reference73). However, a review of currently available data suggested that supplements of [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant) plus [zinc](../minerals/zinc) may reduce the progression of AMD and vision loss in affected individuals [(74)](#reference74). The main evidence came from the Age-Related Eye Disease Study (AREDS). In this clinical trial, participants with borderline to advanced age-related macular degeneration (AMD) were randomized to receive (1) [placebo](../glossary#placebo); (2) antioxidant vitamins (15 mg/day -carotene, of acetate); (3) zinc (80 mg/day) and copper (2 mg/day); or (4) both antioxidant vitamins and zinc and copper [(75)](#reference75). The five-year results indicated that the risk of developing advanced AMD was significantly reduced in those taking zinc with or without antioxidant vitamins. Antioxidant vitamins alone failed to prevent the progression to advanced AMD, even in individuals at higher risk. It was concluded from this study that a combination of antioxidant vitamins and minerals may benefit people with intermediate AMD or advanced AMD in one eye [(74, 76)](#reference74). Type 2 diabetes mellitus [Oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) contributes to the progression of type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) and causes damage to many organs and tissues, including the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas), brain, eyes, peripheral nerves, and kidneys. Evidence from animal studies suggests that vitamin E supplementation could mitigate the role of [oxidative damage](../glossary#oxidative-damage) in the occurrence of diabetes complications (reviewed in [77](#reference77)). In the Alpha-Tocopherol Beta-Carotene cancer prevention (ATBC) trial in male smokers, supplementation with 50 mg/day of synthetic -tocopherol (25 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) had no effect on the risk of incident type 2 diabetes mellitus during the 19-year post-intervention follow-up. Likewise, supplemental vitamin E intake during the trial made no difference on the incidence of macrovascular complications or mortality in participants with established type 2 diabetes [(78)](#reference78). In addition, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 14 [heterogeneous](../glossary#heterogeneity) [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), including 714 type 2 diabetic individuals, found that supplementation with vitamin E (200-1,800 IU/day for 6-27 weeks) had no effect on markers of glycemic control, including [glycated hemoglobin A1c](../glossary#glycated-hemoglobin) (HbA1c) level and measures of fasting glucose and fasting insulin concentrations [(79)](#reference79). Further subgroup analyses indicated that higher doses of vitamin E (>400 IU/day) supplemented for longer periods (>12 weeks) significantly reduced HbA1c level and fasting insulin concentration, suggesting that vitamin E could possibly enhance insulin action and glucose disposal in type 2 diabetic individuals [(79)](#reference79). Another recent meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials found that endothelial function in normal-weight and overweight — but not obese — patients with type 2 diabetes was significantly improved by supplementation with vitamin E and/or vitamin C [(80)](#reference80). Although there is reason to suspect that vitamin E supplementation may have utility in the management of type 2 diabetes, evidence for benefit from large, well-controlled [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) is still lacking. Fatty liver diseases The increasing incidence of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in children and adults in industrialized countries is mainly attributed to the ongoing epidemic of [obesity](../glossary#obesity) and type 2 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus). NAFLD results from the abnormal accumulation of fat (steatosis) in the liver in the absence of heavy alcohol consumption. Although the condition is considered to be largely benign, NAFLD can progress to a more severe disease called nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) with increased [risks](../glossary#risk) [Oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) is thought to be one of the possible mechanisms responsible for prompting [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) processes that can lead to the progression of NAFLD to NASH. There is currently no established treatment for NAFLD and NASH other than interventions that encourage lifestyle changes and the use of medicines to control or treat metabolic disorders [(82)](#reference82). In the multicenter PIVENS (PIoglitazone versus Vitamin E versus placebo for the treatment of Nonalcoholic Steatohepatitis) trial, 247 nondiabetic subjects with NASH were [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design) to receive 30 mg/day of pioglitazone (an insulin-sensitizing IU/day (536 RRR--tocopherol, or a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) for 96 weeks [(83)](#reference83). Only vitamin E supplementation significantly increased the overall rate of improvement in [histological](../glossary#histology) abnormalities that characterize NASH on liver biopsies (i.e., hepatocellular ballooning, steatosis, and lobular [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation)) [(84)](#reference84). Both active treatments improved some markers of liver function (i.e., alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase) [(84)](#reference84). Yet, results from another two-year, [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) — called TONIC for Treatment Of Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease In Children — in 173 children (ages, 8-17 years) with NAFLD failed to observe any significant reduction in blood concentrations of alanine and aspartate aminotransferases either with supplemental vitamin E or with metformin (an anti-diabetic drug; mg/day) compared to placebo [(85)](#reference85). However, vitamin E supplementation significantly improved the overall disease activity score — used to quantify the severity of the disease. In addition, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of another six trials found that vitamin E significantly lowered circulating aminotransferase concentrations in NAFLD and NASH patients, suggesting liver function improvements [(86)](#reference86). Finally, in a small nonrandomized, unblinded, controlled study in 42 obese children (mean age, 8 years) with NAFLD, lifestyle recommendations combined with 600 mg/day of supplemental RRR--tocopheryl acetate for six months reduced markers of oxidative stress and liver dysfunction and improved [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) and the profile of lipid in the blood, when compared to baseline. No such changes in markers of oxidative stress, liver function, and glucose utilization were reported in the lifestyle intervention only group [(87)](#reference87). Further randomized and well-controlled studies are needed to confirm these preliminary findings. Cognitive deterioration and Alzheimer's disease [Mitochondrial](../glossary#mitochondria) dysfunction and [oxidative stress](../glossary#oxidative-stress) are thought to contribute to the onset and/or progression of several [neurodegenerative diseases](../glossary#neurodegenerative-disease), especially [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease) (AD) [(88)](#reference88). The progressive degeneration of [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) cells that accompanies the decline of memory and other [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) functions in subjects with Alzheimer's disease is associated with an intracellular aggregation of Tau fibrils, an extraneuronal accumulation [reduction](../glossary#reduction) ( [redox](../glossary#redox-reaction)) imbalance of complex [etiology](../glossary#etiology). In the brain of patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and those with AD, the level of markers of oxidative damage to [DNA](../glossary#DNA), [proteins](../glossary#protein), and [lipids](../glossary#lipid) is increased, while the expression and activities of [glutathione](../glossary#glutathione) and [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) [enzymes](../glossary#enzyme) are reduced (reviewed in [88](#reference88)). In addition, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) reported that circulating concentrations of vitamins, including vitamin A, vitamin C, and vitamin E, were significantly lower in AD patients than in cognitively healthy individuals [(89)](#reference89). Other studies have documented low concentrations of vitamin E in [cerebrospinal fluid](../glossary#cerebrospinal-fluid) of cognitively impaired patients (reviewed in [90](#reference90)). Because a reduction in oxidative stress may help maintain cognitive status and/or prevent deterioration, the effects of vitamin E supplementation have been assessed in a few [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial). An early multicenter, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in individuals with AD of moderate severity found that supplementation with 2,000 IU/day of all-rac--tocopherol (equivalent to 900 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) for two years significantly delayed cognitive decline, slowed disease progression, and increased median survival [(91)](#reference91). However, a placebo-controlled trial in 769 patients with MCI found that the same dosage of vitamin E did not affect the probability of progression from MCI to AD over a three-year period [(92)](#reference92). In another [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled trial, an improvement in cognitive performance — measured by the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) scoring system — was reported in AD patients randomized to receive 800 IU/day of all-rac--tocopherol (360 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) for six months only when the treatment effectively reduced oxidative stress (as assessed by the measure of total glutathione and markers of [lipid peroxidation](../glossary#lipid-peroxidation) in the blood) [(93)](#reference93). Conversely, a failure to reduce oxidative stress resulted in supplemental vitamin E being more detrimental to the cognitive function of AD patients than placebo. In the most recent multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study, supplemental vitamin E (2,000 IU/day; form of vitamin E not mentioned in the publication) for over two years significantly delayed functional decline — determined by the (in)ability to perform basic activities of daily living — and reduced the annual mortality rate in mild and moderate AD patients [(94)](#reference94). Yet, vitamin E failed to affect cognitive performance measured with MMSE scores and other cognitive ability tests. While there is currently little evidence to suggest that long-term supplementation of vitamin E provides any cognitive benefits in healthy older adults [(95)](#reference95), additional research needs to confirm whether vitamin E supplementation could benefit the management of patients with mild-to-moderate cognitive impairments. Sources Food sources Major sources of -tocopherol in the American diet include vegetable oils (olive, sunflower, and safflower oils), nuts, whole grains, and green leafy vegetables. All eight forms of vitamin E (-, -, -, and -tocopherols and -, -, -, and -tocotrienols) occur naturally in mostly plant-based foods but in varying amounts. Table 2 lists the content of -tocopherol and -tocopherol (in milligrams) in some rich sources of vitamin E. For more information on the vitamin E content of foods, search [USDA's FoodData Central](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/). Table 2. While it appears feasible for individuals to meet the RDA from food only, Americans would have to depart from their current dietary practices and include greater intakes of nuts, seeds, fruit, and vegetables without increasing fat intake above recommended levels [(96)](#reference96). Supplements RRR--tocopherol is the only stereoisomeric form of -tocopherol found in unfortified foods. The same is not always true for nutritional [supplements](../glossary#supplement). Vitamin E supplements generally contain 100 IU to 1,000 IU of -tocopherol. Supplements made from entirely natural sources contain only RRR--tocopherol (wrongly labeled d--tocopherol). RRR--tocopherol is the most [bioavailable](../glossary#bioavailability) form of -tocopherol in the body. Synthetic -tocopherol, which is often found in [fortified](../glossary#fortification) food and nutritional supplements and usually labeled all-rac--tocopherol or dl--tocopherol, include all eight possible stereoisomers of -tocopherol (see [Function](#Function)). Because half of the [isomers](../glossary#isomer) present as a mixture in synthetic -tocopherol are not usable by the body, synthetic -tocopherol is less bioavailable than natural -tocopherol (see [Figure 1](#figure-1)). To calculate the amount (in milligrams) of -tocopherol bioavailable in a supplement, the conversion factors are as follows: - Natural vitamin E (RRR--tocopherol) containing supplements: IU of x 0.67 = mg of RRR--tocopherol Example: 100 IU of natural vitamin E provides 67 mg of RRR--tocopherol - Synthetic vitamin E (all-rac--tocopherol) containing supplements: IU of all-rac--tocopherol x 0.45 = mg of RRR--tocopherol Example: 100 IU of synthetic vitamin E provides 45 mg of 2R--tocopherol In addition, vitamin E-fortified foods often contain synthetic -tocopherol, and amounts of vitamin E are provided as a percentage of the daily value ( [DV](../glossary#DV)) of 30 IU (approximately -Tocopheryl succinate and -tocopheryl acetate are the forms of vitamin E in nutritional [supplements](../glossary#supplement). Tocopherol [esters](../glossary#ester) are more resistant to [oxidation](../glossary#oxidation) during storage than unesterified tocopherols [(1)](#references). When taken orally, the succinate or acetate moieties are removed from -tocopherol in the intestine. The [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) of -tocopherol from -tocopheryl succinate and -tocopheryl acetate is equivalent to that of free -tocopherol [(97)](#reference97). Hence, the conversion factors used to determine the amount of bioavailable -tocopherol provided by -tocopheryl succinate and -tocopheryl acetate are the same as those used for -tocopherol (see [above](#formula)) [(2)](#reference2). Cell culture studies indicated that the vitamin E ester, -tocopheryl succinate, could inhibit [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and induce [apoptosis](../glossary#apoptosis) in a number of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) cell lines [(12)](#reference12). Limited data from animal models of cancer found that -tocopheryl succinate administered by injection inhibited tumor growth [(98)](#reference98). There is currently no evidence in humans that taking oral -tocopheryl succinate supplements delivers -tocopheryl succinate to tissues. Of note, current research investigates nanomedicines to increase -tocopheryl succinate bioavailability before exploring putative nicotinate is another acid ( -tocopheryl nicotinate can be prescribed as a [lipid](../glossary#lipid)-lowering agent in Europe and Japan, it is marketed as a supplement only in the US [(99)](#reference99). -Tocopheryl phosphates (Ester-E®) There is currently no published evidence that [supplements](../glossary#supplement) containing -tocopheryl phosphates are more efficiently absorbed or have greater [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) in humans than those containing -tocopherol [(99)](#reference99). Other supplemental forms [Supplements](../glossary#supplement) containing -tocopherol, mixed tocopherols, or tocotrienols are also commercially available [(99)](#reference99). The amounts of - and -tocopherol in mixed tocopherol supplements vary, so it is important to read the label to determine the amount of each tocopherol form present in a capsule. Safety Toxicity Few side effects have been noted in adults taking [supplements](../glossary#supplement) of less than 2,000 mg of -tocopherol daily (either natural or synthetic vitamin E). However, most studies assessing safety issues or toxicity of -tocopherol supplementation have lasted only a few weeks to a few months, and side effects associated with long-term -tocopherol supplementation have not been adequately studied. The most worrisome possibility is that of impaired blood clotting, which increases the likelihood of [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage) in some individuals. A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that daily vitamin E supplementation — equivalent to 25 to 536 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol — for several years resulted in a significant, 10% reduction in the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [ischemic stroke](../glossary#ischemic-stroke) (five trials, 91,393 participants) and a nonsignificant trend towards an increased risk of [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke) (five trials, 100,748 participants) [(100)](#reference100). A tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) for any form of supplemental -tocopherol (all possible stereoisomers) has been established by the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine to avoid the potential risk of bleeding (Table 3). Specifically, the UL of 1,000 mg/day of -tocopherol in any supplemental form (equivalent to 1,500 IU/day of RRR--tocopherol or 1,100 IU/day of all-rac--tocopherol) corresponds to the highest dose unlikely to result in hemorrhage in almost all adults [(2)](#reference2). Although only certain [isomers](../glossary#isomer) of -tocopherol are retained in the circulation, all forms are absorbed and [metabolized](../glossary#metabolism) by the liver. Hence, the rationale for a UL that refers to all stereoisomers of -tocopherol is based on the fact that any form of -tocopherol (natural or synthetic) can be absorbed and thus be potentially harmful. Table 3. Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL) for -Tocopherol* | Age Group || mg/day# | | Infants 0-12 months || Not possible to establish## | | Children 1-3 years || 200 | | Children 4-8 years || 300 | | Children 9-13 years || 600 | | Adolescents 14-18 years || 800 | | Adults 19 years and older || 1,000 | | | *The UL for -tocopherol applies to all stereoisomers of -tocopherol (natural and synthetic) found in supplements and fortified food. #Of note, mg-to-IU conversion factors are such that the UL in IU for synthetic tocopherol (all-rac--tocopherol) is 1.10 times the UL in mg, and the UL in IU for natural tocopherol (RRR--tocopherol) is 1.50 times the UL in mg. Hence, the UL amount of 1,000 mg for adults corresponds to 1,100 IU of synthetic tocopherol or 1,500 IU of natural tocopherol. ##Source of intake should be from foods or formula only. Some physicians recommend discontinuing high-dose vitamin E supplementation two to four weeks before elective surgery — including dental procedures — to decrease the risk of hemorrhage [(99)](#reference99). Because dietary vitamin E is essential to prevent vitamin E deficiency in the newborn, vitamin E must be supplied in [parenteral nutrition](../glossary#total-parenteral-nutrition) solutions in infants who cannot be given enteral feeding, such as prematurely born infants. Yet, preterm infants appear to be especially vulnerable to adverse effects of -tocopherol supplementation, and supplemental vitamin E should be administered only under controlled supervision by a pediatrician [(101)](#reference101). Finally, the results of only one randomized controlled trial in 601 patients with common forms of retinitis pigmentosa (RP) indicated that supplementation with 400 IU/day of synthetic vitamin E (equivalent to 180 mg/day of RRR--tocopherol) modestly but significantly accelerated the loss of [retinal](../glossary#retina) function compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(22)](#reference22). Patients with common forms of RP should therefore avoid taking high-dose vitamin E supplements if they are not deficient in vitamin E (see [Deficiency](#deficiency)). Does vitamin E supplementation increase the risk of all-cause mortality? A [prospective](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) [observational study](../glossary#observational-study) in over 4,000 participants of the Framingham Heart Study and the Framingham Offspring Study — with or without preexisting [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) — found no statistically significant association between vitamin E supplement intake and [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) or all-cause mortality after a 10-year follow-up period [(102)](#reference102). However, in addition to reports of increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage) and heart failure with supplemental vitamin E in several [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) (see [Cardiovascular disease](#cardiovascular-disease-prevention)), a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) by Miller et al. [(103)](#reference103) suggested an increased risk of death with the use of large doses of vitamin E, yet lower than the UL. Specifically, this meta-analysis combined the results of 19 clinical trials of vitamin E supplementation that mostly focused on secondary prevention and, as such, included subjects with pre-existing conditions including heart disease, end-stage [renal](../glossary#renal) failure, and [Alzheimer's disease](../glossary#alzheimer-disease). The study found that daily supplementation with at least 400 IU of synthetic vitamin E (equivalent to 180 mg of RRR--tocopherol) resulted in a 4% increase in risk of death from any cause compared to [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(103)](#reference103). However, further dose-response analysis and adjustment for intake of other vitamin and mineral supplements indicated that all-cause mortality risk was significantly increased by 7% only at a dose of 2,000 IU/day, which is notably higher than the UL for adults (1,100 IU/day of synthetic tocopherol or 1,500 IU/day of natural tocopherol; see [Table 3](#table-3)). Additionally, a more recent meta-analysis of 46 randomized trials, including 171,244 participants, found that supplemental vitamin E, singly or in combination with other [antioxidants](../glossary#antioxidant), did not significantly alter the risk of all-cause mortality [(104)](#reference104). At present, there is no convincing evidence that vitamin E supplementation below the UL increases the risk of death from cardiovascular disease or other causes, especially in generally healthy subjects. Yet, individuals with pre-existing conditions may be at increased risk of serious adverse effects (including death) if one considers the possibility that large doses of supplemental vitamin E might interfere with medications, and possibly lower their efficacy or increase their toxicity [(1)](#references). Nutrient interactions Large doses of vitamin E may inhibit [vitamin K](vitamin-K)-dependent carboxylase activity and interfere with the [coagulation](../glossary#coagulation) cascade (see the article on [Vitamin K](vitamin-K#nutrient-interactions)) [(19)](#reference19). Hence, the use of vitamin E [supplements](../glossary#supplement) may increase the risk of bleeding in individuals taking [anticoagulant](../glossary#anticoagulant) drugs (blood thinners), such as heparin and the vitamin including aspirin, ibuprofen, and others. In addition, individuals who may be vitamin K deficient due to liver failure, those with a propensity to bleed (e.g., bleeding [peptic ulcers](../glossary#peptic-ulcer-disease)), and those with inherited bleeding disorders (e.g., hemophilia) or a history of [hemorrhagic stroke](../glossary#hemorrhagic-stroke), should not take -tocopherol supplements without close medical supervision because of the increased risk of [hemorrhage](../glossary#hemorrhage) [(20](#reference20), [99)](#reference99). Finally, it cannot be excluded that vitamin E would potentiate the antithrombotic activity of supplemental fish oils and herbal products, such as garlic, curcumin, or Ginkgo biloba [(99)](#reference99). Drug interactions A number of cholestyramine and colestipol), as well as orlistat, sucralfate, mineral oil, and the fat substitute, olestra, which interfere with fat absorption, may theoretically decrease the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin E. The [anticonvulsant](../glossary#anticonvulsant) drugs phenobarbital, phenytoin (Dilantin), and carbamazepine (Tegretol), may also in with [epilepsy](../glossary#epilepsy) [(105)](#reference105). trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in 160 patients [coronary heart disease](../glossary#coronary-heart-disease) (CHD) and low high-density-lipoprotein ( [HDL](../glossary#HDL)) levels found that a combination of simvastatin (Zocor) and [niacin](niacin) increased the HDL2 subfraction level (considered most cardioprotective), inhibited the progression of [coronary artery](../glossary#coronary-artery) [stenosis](../glossary#stenosis) (narrowing), and decreased the frequency of [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, such as [myocardial infarction](../glossary#myocardial-infarction) and [stroke](../glossary#stroke) [(106)](#reference106). Surprisingly, when an [antioxidant](../glossary#antioxidant) combination of 1,000 mg of vitamin C, 800 IU (536 mg) of RRR--tocopherol, 100 g of selenium, and 25 mg of -carotene daily, was taken with the simvastatin-niacin combination, the protective effects were diminished. However, in a much larger randomized controlled trial of simvastatin and an antioxidant combination of 600 mg of all-rac--tocopherol (297 mg of RRR--tocopherol), 250 mg of vitamin C, and 20 mg of -carotene daily in more than 20,000 men and women with CHD or diabetes, the antioxidant combination did not adversely affect the cardioprotective effects of simvastatin therapy over a five-year period [(107)](#reference107). These contradictory findings indicate that further research is needed on potential interactions between antioxidant supplementation and cholesterol-lowering agents like statins. Linus Pauling Institute Recommendation The Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) for vitamin E for adult men and women is 15 mg (22.5 IU) per day. Notably, more than 90% of individuals two years of age and older in the US do not meet the daily requirement for vitamin E from food sources alone. Therefore, LPI recommends that generally healthy adults (aged 19 years and older) take a daily [multivitamin/mineral (MVM) supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements), which usually contains 30 IU of synthetic vitamin E — equivalent to 13.5 mg of RRR--tocopherol and 90% of the RDA. Older adults (>50 years) The Linus Pauling Institute's recommendation to take a daily [multivitamin/mineral (MVM) supplement](../micronutrients-health/multivitamin-mineral-supplements) containing vitamin E is also appropriate for generally healthy older adults. MVMs typically contain 30 IU of synthetic vitamin E, covering 90% of the [RDA](../glossary#RDA).
